author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Relieving patients of their pain
text:
The prescription medicine OxyContin. (Darren McCollester/Getty Images) October 25 at 8:13 PM The Oct. 21 editorial “ Lifesaving guidelines ” gave undeserved praise to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s flawed approach to addressing the serious problem of opioid addiction.
Without question, federal health agencies such as the CDC must address the misuse of prescription pain medication. But prescribing guidelines for doctors must be evidence-based to have a positive impact. By the CDC’s own admission, each of its recommendations is based on weak or insubstantial evidence . In addition, the panel that reviewed the proposed guidelines failed to include researchers with expertise in pain management. This led the CDC to propose guidelines that show little regard for patients with cancer and other painful, chronic illnesses.
